She is a strict vegan and so eats a bit of salad. In the last scan (after the second round of chemo), the doc did observe some reduction in size in the lungs. Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2011 07:08AM gramana wrote: Thank you. Here is her current treatment regime: She has to go through 6 cycles and she will start her fouth tomorrow the 10th Oct. The doctor is administering the drug in 2 rounds within each cycle. first cycle:-    1st round - gencitabine 2 grams and zoledronic acid 4mg.   2nd round - gencitabine 2grams Second cycle:-   1st round - gencitabine 2 grams and zoledronic acid 4mg.   2nd round - gencitabine 2grams Third cycle:-   1st round - gencitabine 1.4g grams and zoledronic acid 4mg.   2nd round - gencitabine 1.4grams Fouth cyle:- (due on 10th Oct'2011 and planned as of now)  1st round - gencitabine 1.4g grams and zoledronic acid 4mg  2nd round - gencitabine 1.4grams X-ray of chest after the 1st cycle and the 3rd cycle Blood work after every round. Blood work good so far. After the 1st cycle she had the tingling on her face and hands but that has subsided subsequently. She feels weak for a few days after the chemo and picks up strength after the 3rd or thr day.

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2011 07:49AM gramana wrote: My mother, her BP is on the higher side and she has been on the BP medicine for years. She completed her 4th chemo cycle and as always she continued to take her BP medicine. She has been complaining of weakness/tiresomeness which we attributed to the chemo, but suprisingly learnt today that her BP has fallen drastically to the 60s. The doc did a ECG and general checkup and found her heart and other functions to be fine. Is this something you all have experienced / come across? Any input/guidance would be of great help. As always, very greatful. Regards Ramana

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 11:53AM gramana wrote: I thought of sharing this with you all..something I came across today... Metastasis Mechanism Identified Drug Discovery & Development - November 04, 2011 Scientists at Dalhousie University in Nova Scotia have identified a key mechanism of metastasis that could lead to blocking tumor growth if their findings are confirmed. Lead researcher David Waisman, PhD, professor in the departments of biochemistry and molecular biology and pathology detailed the role the macrophage cell surface protein S100A10 plays in allowing macrophages to move to the site of tumor growth-a process that is essential to tumor development. Waisman says the findings are an example of the complicated biology of cancer. "We used to think that the only cells that mattered in a tumor were the cancer cells, and that's it, but now we are beginning to see that other cells must collaborate with cancer cells to drive tumor growth and permit an evolution of the cancer cells into metastatic cells. This change is what causes poor prognosis and ultimately what kills the patient," he says. Waisman and colleagues discovered that tumors will not grow without macrophage assistance. These macrophages must come from the blood or from other locations in the tissues. How they are able to move through the tissues or from the blood supply into the tumor had always been a mystery. These macrophages need to chew their way through the tissue that forms a barrier around the growing tumor in order to move into the tumor site and combine with the cancer cells. The researchers found on the outside surface of the macrophage is a protein called S100A10, which enables the macrophage to remove the tissue barriers retarding migration to the tumor site. Theoretically, blocking either the macrophages or S100A10 chemically could slow, or even stop, tumor growth. "We found that the protein, S100A10, acts like a pair of scissors on the outside of the macrophages that empowers the macrophages with the ability to chew their way through tissues and enter the tumor site where they release substances that stimulate cancer cell growth and metastatic evolution," says Waisman. The next step is to figure out how S100A10 functions as a molecular scissor and also to identify pharmaceutical agents that can block the action of S100A10, thereby preventing the movement of macrophages to the tumor site. By understanding exactly how S100A10 works at the molecular level, it may be possible to design agents which block its activity. The discovery was published in Cancer Research. Release Date: Oct. 31, 2011
